Lightly hazy deep golden.  Abundant carbonation (duh!).  Nose is pure Blaugies dust, hay, flinty steely dry, touch of iron.  Faintest whiff of fruit.  Ernest is spot on with the cantaloupe and hints of grapes.   Medium dryness, not as dry as the Epeature from Blaugies.  More minerally water/earthy yeast character so distinctive of Blaugies.  Some surprising hoppiness near the finish.  This stuff is so simple, yet so elegant, in a rustic sort of way.  This is the kind of beer that makes me buy crusty bread, good cheese and good sausage, and sit back and relish in the sensual pleasure of life.

Sampled at the Milwaukee YEHa!05 courtesy of MIBRomeo: Hazy dark bronze pour has a lightly-lacing white head.  Sweet, lightly fruity citrus and Belgian malty and yeasty aroma.  Starts with tart, sour fruit backed with a malty base and a dry, tart finish.  Im not a big fan of the tartness, but with a little more balance, this could be quite nice.

Hazy amber with a great head, looking appetizing as all the Blaugies beers (giving the same excitement when uncorking also).Vinous aroma, almost geuze-like, lemony freshness meeting oak woodiness. Lots of lemon flavours, some yeastiness, oaky vanilla, talcum-powder dryness like in a Girardin. Very fizzy, prickling the tongue. Complex, yet refreshing. One of the beers that convinces you of the supremacy of Belgian brewing!

Very hazy orange/amber with a thick, lasting off-white head.  Nice sweetish aroma.  Some spicy corianderish notes.  Fairly full-bodied and quite yeasty.  Some sweet cherry and light bubble gum in the finish.  Slightly tart, dryish finish.  Pretty tasty, but I dont really get any figgy character at all.

Golden-beige colour, very hazy, big head.  Yeasty, slightly figgy/fruity aroma.  The palate is quite yeasty as well, with an underlying fruity sweetness.  Not hugely different, nor expressive, just a decent Belgian ale.
Cloudy light brown body, not much head.  Tart yeast, mandarin orange, pale malt aroma.  Brett tartness, lemon peel, grass, and sugar wafer sweetness.  Great combo of tartness and Belgian-y sweetness.
Cloudy amber with a large white head. Light nose with yeast, black pepper and toffee. Tart flavor, medium sweet with fruity notes, grapes, apple, yeast. A bit overly effervescent.

Pours dirty orange with huge white head. Tons of sediment floating around. Sour/tart lemon aroma, very yeasty with some barnyard funkiness. Flavor much the same with faint hint of sour cherry, very drying mouthfeel/finish. Will agree with others, couldnt detect any fig whatsoever. Maybe masquerading as cherry?

Dark orange body with a big foamy white head. Yeasty aroma with some dust, dark cherries and a touch of barnyard as well. Lightly tart, some wheat, cherries and figs. Finishes dry. I detected more cherry flavor rather than figs, but either way this was very enjoyable.

Milwaukee YEHa!05, brought by MIBRomeo.  Murky burnt orange body, thin persistent off-white head.  Nice spicy aroma, but also sourish, with hints of grape (gotta be the fig), wood, and even a bit of cheese rind.  Tart, estery body (fruits in abundance- orange, lemons, etc.), and a bit spicy, but mostly a tad sour and herbal.  Rather tannic, too.  Soft, tea-like body with just the right sour kick.  Unique and quite tasty.

Aroma is celery-ish aroma with some sour cherries some minerals, nice.  Cloudy, straw yellow with a thin head.  Sour, tart and lemony with a citrusy sharp flavor.  Slightly musty and very interesting.  Dry finish with a hint of spice.  Thanks to Chuck and Blake.

Very hoppy (Flemish hops, maybe) and fruity aroma.  Pours a huge white head, persistent, but not very compact. Amber in colour. Mouthfeel is dry and a little sour, medium bodied, lightly bitter and flavour is hoppy and spicy. I didnt notice any fig note. Delicious, indeed.

Another explosive beer from Brasserie de Blaugies. When opened it just came foaming out, which gives it a huge head when first poured, but the head collapses only leaving slight curtains on the glass, but there are yeast specs in the off-white head. And the beer is an unclear orange. The aroma is quite sweet and quite fruity combined with hints of spice and yeast, but also a touch of dustiness. The flavor is sweet fruity combined with a slight acidity like a grapefruit, and is quite spicy with coriander and cloves. The end is very dry - spicy and woody. I dont pick up the figs.

Cloudy, bold and muted orange in color with tight bubbly lace cascading slowly down the sides of the tulip like a custom wedding invitation.  Sugary fruit salad served out of a grapefruit core comes to call for the aromatic portion of the show, meeting up with lemons used in place of the ball in a farmhouse softball match, not to mention the anticipated fig additives.  Lovely souring nodes break open the palate door with fig-like tangerine suggestions.  Takes that lime juice thats been sitting on the fridge door for years and makes a tasty wonder out of it.  Some sugar-saturated Lemon Heads with double the coating.  Such a tasty deviation from the standard run of the mill.  Thanks for sharing MIBRomeo!

cloudy off orangish yellow w/ a full white head and some nice lacing.  Has that murky aroma and some yeast and floral hops hints of a lambicy horseblanket.  Highly carbonated palate good body.  Lightly sour and fruity apricot & fig lightly acidic has a tart finish.  hints of a floral hop.  Pretty good.

Chuck and I picked this up in Minnesota.  The beer pours to a straw colored murky body with a thin white head.  The aroma is a floral and citrusy Belgian yeasted beer.  The flavor is grassy and vinous.  Oaky and tart.  i love the tartness of this.

[Bottle 750ml, dates unknown, chilled]
Cloudy amber with a tan and frothy head. Exceptionally complex nose since it has a bit of everything:  citrus, floral, raisins, vineous/grassy feels, barnyard well, at the end, it is supposed to smell figs, but Im not certain about that. Taste is unpredictable. Oak/Barrel/aged ? Acidic for sure. Texture is medium and carbonation is high. Very interesting beer and I understand why it only fits into the general Ale category since its definitely a one of its kind.

Musty, barnyard nose that is mostly sweet. Orange color, tight bubbled head with lacing. Light fruity malt, yeasty notes. Tart, lactic end. Medium body. Reserved overall, but sophisticated and complex.

I like this drink, even though (or, perhaps, because) I cant detect the figs in it anywhere.  Hazy dark straw body, some particles, and a dense, creamy head, most of which hangs around for the length of the drink.  The aroma is quite yeasty with a citric tartness and a lightly bitter grassiness.  Soft bodied, it has a refreshingly, lightly sour flavor of grapefruit, yeast and a lively spiciness... but, no figs.  The finish is refreshingly tart.  I could drink alot of this.  Whilst eating figs.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Wine & Spirits, Chicago, IL<font size=-1>
Deep orange color, medium head - some floating but that might have been because of wrong pouring. Grapefruit and grass nose. Again mustard seeds and also cellery nose.

Bottled. Delirium Cafe, Gothenburg, Sweden.
Hazy orange, large white head, loads of yeast.
Soruish and grassy aroma; cedar.
Dry and sour flavour with late bitterness.
Marcipan. Too thin.
(750ml bottle, 2004 vintage)  Pours a cloudy orange body with a frothy beige head.  Aroma of mustiness, citrus, florals, and raisins.  Flavor of spicy yeast, and citrus with a lively carbonation.
Orange color with lots of yeast. Nice white head. Hoppy, grassy aroma with citrus, hay and some wheat. Hoppy sourish flavorsome spices, grapefruit and gooseberries. A bit thin.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2006 What a rustic and happy beer! I still dont get any fig anywhere, but Im not worried about it in the least.

Light amber-gold color, clear with a large, frothy, off-white mostly lasting head.

Aromas are dreamy barn-yard: malty with moderate notes of toasted grain, brown rice and cookie; hoppy with light-to-moderate herbs, straw and lemon zest; yeasty with light notes of dough, moderate horseblanket and barnyard, trace band-aid; miscellaneous notes of light spicy alchs, milk, starchy banana and clove.

The flavor is moderately bitter, lightly sweet and moderately tangy-acidic with a long, lightly acidic, lightly bitter, warm finish.

Palate is nice:body is light, the texture is watery-to-velvety and the carbonation is lively.

Bottled. Sampled at Delirium Café, Göteborg. 
Hazy dark yellow. Cellary, vineous nose with notes of green apples. Wheaty flavour profile(wheat was added, yes?), but not sour, nor smooth. Flavour is extremely short, but oaky with an aged, cellary feel.

Pours a hazy golden yellow color. Lots of floaties and a small white head. Aroma is lemon corriander, herbs, (sage, allspice) Flavor is astringent, lemon zest corriander, pine needles. Slightly acidic finish.

Ultra carbonated with a 6" thick head. Lighter in color than I was expecting. Mineral, hay and CO2 aroma. Very tart and dry with some bitterness in the finish. I dont get any fig in the flavor, though it is a bit fruity. If I had to classify it, I would call it a Saison. Pretty nice, though a little flat in the flavor profile.
June, 2005.  Bottle @ Catford Beer festival.  Lively but soft carbonation. Slightly herbal and acidic aroma. Slightly off flavour. Not enjoyable.

The body is dark orange with some hazy character. The aroma is definitely figs. It also has some herbal notes. The smell is earthy and rich. The taste is a little tart with notes of the figs. It also has some mushrooms and a little bit of oranges. Fruity and different. I like the finish, it isnt dry or too sweet. Nicely done.

Really nice beer. Cork flew out of the bottle with little resistance. Pours an apricot colored brew with a huge white head. Flavors hint at peaches and mangos with a slight underlying yeast funkiness. Very enjoyable.
Golden hazy with a bit of chunkage. Aroma reminds me a skrumpy apple cider which must be from the fig juice.

750ml corked bottle and served in my St. Bernardus chalice: A careful pour displayed a lovely orange and golden hue toppped by a long lasting frothy head and above average lace. The aroma has notes of orange zest, fig, strawberry, flowery and herbal yeast esters, mint, light pepper and saffron. The nose finds this combination very appealing indeed! The taste starts with a  quick dose of acidic fruitiness followed quickly by a very yeasty and hay like quality. Some subdued funk and very wispery spice highlight the short and dry finish. Lingering lemony and earthy nature. No notice of fig on the palate. The feel is quite lively and very carbonated, could almost say too much. A nice beer and easy to embrace but lack the depth of palate to match the aroma. I would not turn down another chance to try it.

Bright orange color.  Enormous saison froth, which lasts.  Unbelievable array of fruits in the nose with hints of lemon, orange, peach and nectarine; distinctly Blaugies but also distinctly Dupont.  Dry and spritzy, slightly tart and just loaded with orange, peach, pear, a total fruit platter with hints of Dupont yeast.  No fig flavor noted on the palate, but thats ok.  I just love this brewery.

75cl bottle, cork dated 2004.  Big frothy head, strong bead, and lovely cloudy orange color...Laura opened the back door, and the setting sun shone through to where my full glass sat next to me...and my beer began to glow the most magnificent orange color Ive ever seen.  Incredibly dry and earthy on the palate...the trouble I have with this and their saison is the incredible dryness, the yeast just seems to strip the beer to the level of a brut champagne or something, and initially, at least, I feel like this has robbed the beer of the typical beery flavors...the nose is hay, wood, earth, subtle fruit like apples...I feel that any complexity in this beer comes in the finish, the lingering...and that makes it very much its own.  A nice drink for sure, subtle and dry and bubbly, but I certainly lean more towards the Monuesse for luxuriant drinking.  With time, this one might grow on me more, but I still find it a bit bland.

(Bottle 75 cl) Golden with a gigantic head and the typical Blaugies super carbonation. Lovely dry with some undefinable spices - none that appears very fig-like though. Actually this is more down Orval alley, although without the refined complexity of this beer. But still a nice one. 111097

Fluffy and abundant carbonation tickles the nose with tiny pinpricks then settles into a warm mouthbuzz as it warms.  Medium, mineralized, soft and slippery body.  Aroma of prickly pears, figs, bananas, dough, yeast, salt, flowers, a bit of funk like a slightly damp musty root cellar in the chill fall, musk?, and sweet honey-like malt.  Taste is warm, round, yeasty, fruity, some sweet herbal/spice notes, and lots of sweetness nicely balanced by some peppery acidity and light funk.  Finish is long, sweet, and smooth, with an herbal fruity aftertaste.  Impressive and drinkable, a lovely beer.

Bottle. Quite a yeasty dry ale. Quite subtle in flavour, with some apple, flowers and citrus in aroma and flavour. Nice soft carbonation, with some pepper and herbs in the finish, quite nice, soft and drinkable.

Its made with fig juice?  Its certainly noticeably fruity but I certainly wouldnt have picked out figs.  More grapey Id say. But then Ive never had a beer involving figs before so I dont really know I might expect fermented fig juice to taste like. Cloudy, orangey colour. Dry and a bit musty, with a fair amount of acidity on the finish. Some citrus. Drinks quite easily but didnt really get me going (so to speak). Bottled, at Catford Beer Festival 2005.

Cloudy orange with a moderate to low carbonation and a nice lasting head but not much lace.  moderately fruity and yeasty aroma with some citrus.  Also some slightly hot and spicy hints in the aroma as it warms.  Really smooth slightly tart flavor, malty, yeasty, herbal, and earthy- almost woodsy.  Good body with a nice slightly citrusy, acidic and tart finish.  Unlike any other beer I have had.  Not excellent but pretty good overall.

Bottled 375cl (BBE 2007)
Dark hazy orange, lots of big yeast particles, big foamy beige head. Fresh, yeasty and lemony aroma. Light, metallic, citrusy, weizen like beer with earthy notes. Oily, earthy, fruity aftertaste.

from a bottle served up by a Shelton Bro Dan at brewtopia.  cloudy golden yellow color, short white head.  aroma is funky, raisin, cherry, fig.  yes, I also would not have guessed fig, but Dan enlightened me.  very creamy mouthfeel, slightly sour, yeasty, slightly dry.  thanks Shelton Bros!

750 mL, corked & caged (unknown vintage, purchase June 2003, sampled April 2005): pretty pathetic cork removal, disappointingmust have waited to long with this one.  No carbonation.  Clear orange amber.  Sweet, fruity aromatics, light malt and hints of alcohol.  Also noticeable are a bit of must and significant cork.  Sweet and tart grape flavour that is quickly diminishing on the tongue, but leaves me with a strange satisfaction.  Though this one is clearly not it top condition, neither the aroma nor the flavour give indications of infection.  I am off to find a fresh bottle...

Bottle at Spring Brewtopia 2005... Poured from the bottom of the bottle so I got a ton of yeast. Totally murky, pear-colored ale. Apple esters, light smoke and spiced pear. Perfectly balanced. Pleasantly tart and spicy. Lightly sweet. Medium-bodied and fizzy. Crisp, clean, very dry finish.
Brewtopia 05. Hazy brown/orange body with off white head. I smelled raisins and other dark fruit. Taste was the same, lots going on. Very nice.

750ml. bottle sampled at Brewtopia 05.
Cloudy orange color with a small off white head. Aroma was very yeasty and fruity. You can smell the dark fruits,
but I wouldnt have guessed figs unless Dan Shelton had mentioned it to me. Quite musty, very much like a saison.
Fruity malt flavor that was fairly dry and very refreshing. Was informed that a liquor store an hour from me carries this. I will definitely pick some up.
Spicy and tart nose with a bit of wheat and bread. Dry and herbal with notes of banana, cloves, cardamom, pears and prunes. Slightly sour and grassy with a lingering herbal finish.

Bottled. Cloudy golden with rich head and lots of sediment. Fruity,lightly raisiny aroma. Sweetish with pleasant malt and yeast character. The body is however a bit thin, an the character of the fig juice and hardly noticable. Subtle, and a bit lacking in body.

This beer poured a cloudy orange color w/ thin head and lacing.  The aroma had soury fermented fruit, lemons, and flowers.  The flavor had crisp citrus, flowers, caramel, and light fermented fruit.  The mouthfeel was light and slightly carbonated.
Pours a cloudy orange hue with a small white head.  Aroams of oranges, spice, and a light yeast funk.   Mouthfeel is light bodied with flavors of spice, honey, pears, and a hint of caramel.

Light hazy orange-amber with faint greenisch skim in it. Nice fluffy white-yellow head with a light fizzy carracter. Discreet nose with touches of fresh yeast, spring-flowers, faint citrus, cookies, light honeyed but overall dry and refreshing aromas. The taste of this beer is dry, light fruity, flowery, peppery-spicy, touches of corn-bread, nuts and a very fine well hidden minty-citrussy accent. Overall a very fine and refreshing beer with an original and refreshing afthertaste.

Bottle.  Very hazy orange color with different sized particles.  Head is big and foamy with yeast specks.  Aroma is earthy and a yeasty.  Has a nice juicy pear mouth feel which finishes sour with a little floral hops.  Very interesting, very good.  (wheres the fig?)
750 ml bottle.  Hazy golden in color with a nice thick white head. Typical saison aroma. Fig, clove and banana notes. Malty and smooth flavor. Nice beer. Slightly sour on the palate. Enjoyale.

750 ml bottle. Hazy golden with a thick white head. Aroma is typical of a saison, with notes of fig, banana, clove, and maybe even barnyard. Smooth and malty flavor with a nice bit of funk. Slightly sour on the palate. Some dryness. Maybe the fig character comes through, but I am not sure that I know what that is. Very refreshing drink.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Hazy Orange Coloring.  White Frothy Head.  Carbonated....Spice..Coriander/Saffron?  Yeasty.. Some Fruit as Well..  Different But Certainly Not a Bad Brew to Try.

Bright yellow w/thick huge head. Vanilla, and sour citrus on the nose. Med weight w.creamy dry finish. Citrus, vanilla, some fruit, and a faint mustiness present themselves on the palate. Light delicate adn ethereal.

RBMNG 10/30/04. This one got lumped into "flight #2", the mid heavies, instead of "flight #1", the ligher brews. And, perhaps its rating suffered some from the resulting comparisons. Hemp and champagne-like aroma. Highly carbonated like champagne. Huge, tight bubble head. Hazy boddy. Dry and sophisticated. Somewhat like a gueuze. Lacks sweetness. Nice, just not spectacular.
Hazy dark yellow with a towering head.  A little malt and fruit in the aroma and taste.  Heavily carbonated, almost painfully so.  Bitter as well.

This cloudy amber ale pours with a nice brownish-white head, like a farmhouse or saison ale. The fig juice adds a slight fruity flavor, but is not overpowering. I followed a fresh bottle with one I had aged for over two years (by mistake), and found that most of  the flavor had disappeared, so drink it fresh. This rating applies to the fresh bottle only.
Brewtopia [04.  Peachy color, substantial white head.  Malty and quite sweet, fruit-syrupy.  Ends rather abruptly, acidic.  Sticky lace.

Murky orange brown in color with a large off white head that is nicely retained.  Aroma is slightly funky with a bit of dustiness and some light fruit and yeast.  YUM!  This is a dry, carbonated beverage.  Flavor is quite restained with some light maltiness a bit of yeast and just enough funk to bring a bit of interest.  Not as good as La Moneuse, but still a very nice summer ale.

Bottle conditioned, (750ml) from Dranken Geers via John White. Hazy amber, good longlasting fluffy white head and gentle condition. Muted sweet yeast and caramel in the nose with a touch of fruitiness. Slightly tangy and fruity in the mouth, quite thin with a metallic edge. Any fig notes where lost on me. Finish is malty and has a yeast dryness. Nothing special.

(Bottled, 0.375l) Muddy (with yeast), amber-orange color with medium, foamy head. Earthy, dry and fruity aroma. Sourish, fruity (apple juice) and yeasty flavor. Medium-bodied, quite carbonated palate. Not my style of beer, but quite drinkable anyway.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2005 Plump figs contribute to the citrusy hay aroma...Fluffiness almost overtakes the crunchy wheat and creates a dryness in the feel...Creative simplicity in the Belgian countryside...

Sweet hay, mild camomile, citrus lemon and gentle earthy barnyard aroma. Opaque golden with orange-white head that recedes to cover. Plenty of yeast in suspension. Flavour is fruity, yeasty, and quite herbal  with earthy balancing bitterness. Very structured, fluffy, medium-light body with noticeable though light carbonation on the tongue. Very enjoyable. Bottle (enjoyed with MartinT, Rastacouere and some non-RB tasters).

Brewtopia 04. Orange color with nice sized head. Aroma of dried fruits and yeast. Lively mouthfeel, very carbonated. Malty taste that turns almost sour. I was told by a rep that there was fig syrup added to this which could explain some of the sweetness. Nice lacing throughout.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2004 Superb off-white head with huge foamy lacing levitates above the light amber murky hue. Terrific looking! Aroma comes out extremely yeasty (sawdust, cobwebs), but well balanced by passion fruit notes (mango, figs, grapes). Very fruity on the tongue, dusty yeast, woody. Light citric acidity from the start to the beginning, balancing farmy bitterness in the second half. Yeasty aftertaste with a bit of malty acidity. Mouthfeel is top notch, meringous-like, very bubbly, airy, foamy. A contemplative and unique ale with tremendous garage character to set apart from other belgian ales.

This bottled corked and caged sample poured a extremely large sized invigorated head of foamy finely sized off-white colored long lasting bubbles that left behind an average lacing.  The body was a softly carbonated hazy dark yellow color.  The aroma was fruity with apricot dusty musty yeasty doughy notes to it.  The mouth feel was mildly tingly and smooth with a lingering malt dough aftertaste.  The flavor contained notes of malts mild hops yeast dough and mild fruits.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2004 2003 750mL bottle.  Pours a rusty orange-amber with some dark yellows and golds.  Good light yellow head with lots of sediment flecks, quite hazy and of course, bottle conditioned.  Aroma of honey, almonds, coriander or light curacao, mild but flavorful yeast and a light but tart yellow/green fruit smell.  Flavor is lightly sweet, hints of toffee and light caramel with plenty of dough, almost like a raisin oatmeal cookie.  The yeast is not very funky yet, making me somewhat regret my decision to open this young.  Still, a well-balanced, mild flavor, a touch of wateriness, lots more malt on the finish and a good, moderately carbonated medium-full body.  Very drinkable, dripping with quality.  I would have NEVER guessed figs. . . .

Bottle. Huge off-white head that was long lasting and fine-small sized bubbles. Carbonated, cloudy-hazy and a golden hue. Malty, sweet, fruity, and tart aroma. Flavor is sweet, sour and tart with a tingly mouthfeel. Fair lacing.
Good first impression: amber body and small particules, aroma of apple (fig ??). The flavour was not really impressive despite a medium duration with the final fruity bouquet. Not exceptional.
Golden color; wonderful perlage; huge rocky head. Very nice Triple aroma: coriander, cork, light yeast. Quite dry mouthfeel, with a very light sourness, but below expectations.

Really nothing special in my book. I really expected more. Decent color and active head that went away as quickly as it came. Nose was grassy. Medium body and nothing else to make it stand ouot. Fig juice? Never tasted it.

Starts with the expected Blaugies super cork shooter  - we expected that and all of us protected our eyes as it ricocheted off the ceiling.  I thought this would be darker - I was thinking of plum/prune juice maybe?  Nice golden color - slightly hazed, huge head, great lacing.  Sour/tart/yeast/herbal/pepper saison tastes with a very mild sweetness at the end - that must have been the figs.  Another winner from this tiny brewery

750 ml bottle, no date.  Opaque orange, giant head – lasts forever.  Strongly yeasty nose, no sweetness; Psychprof has it with sourdough.  Bit peppery.  I do taste just a hint of figgy fruitiness..relatively sweet, very yeasty, very full-bodied.  Very soft and creamy as it warms, almost biere de garde-like.  Though this was just OK at the beginning, but by the end I was totally won over.

Beautiful orange gold, with flecks of stuff milling about inside. Smells very fresh, with some sort of sourdough bread and tart fruit smell. Slightly sweet, very crisp and carbonated, thinnish but not overly so. Some metallic notes. Delicious. Less funky, somehow, then the other Blaugies.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: 2000.  40% cloudy, golden body.  60% expansive, fluffy white head.  Fresh aroma of floral perfume, grass, lemon and light fruit.  A touch of funk and some herbal qualities as well.  Light, airy body with strong effervescence.  Tartness dominates the flavor.  The fig juice must be somewhat tart, as the lightly cheesy funk.  A really enjoyable beer with great flavors and new horizons.

Creamy golden color with a nonstop head of despeckled cream colored foam. Even after pour the first glass, albeit small, I looked back to see more foam coming out of the bottle. Aromas of light citrus, mild yeast and ndertones of toasty malt and light fruit(yes, fig included). Certainly not overpowering, but one that makes you sit back and think. Light and crisp body. Light fruity start that is quietly lifted away with a the effervecience and a light grape tartness. Clean and crisp. Ever so slight malt finish brings things back.  Well brewed and an enjoyable quaff.
Extreme Beerfest '04, Deep golden in color with with chunks floating among the haze,no head.Fruity,some rasin like maybe fig charcater.Malty and slightly sweet/sour.
Hazy orange coloured. Notes of fruits and yeast. Slightly sour flavour. Slightly thin. I did not notice the fig juice.
Murky orange with big white head. slightly fruity aroma, bubble gum. Fairly thin, soft, I tasted some figs (as expected).

(slightly aged) Very hazy golden-orange, with loads of little flecks, presenting themselves very conspiciously on the virgin-white, full head. Vegetables and a sweetness in the nose, probably due to the fig syrup. Bit sourish as well. Sourish - but not much - taste, faint spicey and some fruit. No sweetness at all in the taste - I guess due to the ageing. Young this is sweeter, betraying the fig character. Quite dry, bit sharp-sourish finish. Nice - but this is probably one of the few beers I prefer young.

An extremely subtle, hard-to-understand ale. Poured glistening sunshine, soapy head several inches high. Sharp, puckering, vinegary/moss aroma. Heavily carbonated. I really had to get into this beer to get past the extremely subtle (some say bland) flavors of apple juice, champagne yeast and not a lot else.

Foggy golden. Fluffy, large-bubbled dusty-white head. Fragrant, farmy aroma of lemon juice, hay, fresh flowers, earth, sponge cake, melon, and perfume. Beautifully full, yet at the same time, airy, musty, and flowery. Perfectly placed lightly spicy yeast and zingy hops. Soft medium body. More prickly than it is airy. Spicy start transitions beautifully into an elegant middle of fresh hop leaf, perfume, and flowers. Finishes round, mellow and highly appetizing with a persistently spicy,  earthy quality concluding with a light doughy yeast, spicy hop  tingle. The aroma is exquisitely mellow, touting its clean yeast character and well-utilized hop profile with fervency. Im tempted to call this a Saison. Its very farmy, elegantly funky, and perfumey. Another stunner from these garage-based brewers. Give me a plate of mussels and Im good to go.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Dark blond beer with a huge disappearing white head. Weak sour and hop aroma. The taste is sour bitter and rather weak.
Slight hazy dark golden color with a large white head. The taste is mild fruity, slight sweet, with strange finish.

Hugely carbonated. Leaps out of the bottle into the glass and all over the counter. Huge head needed a restraining order.
Clear-ish golden colour. grass, yeast and apples in the aroma.
Tangy and very spritzy taste. Lime and other fruit: pears and, I suppose, figs. Slight brett aftertaste.  Warming alcohol Felt more than 5.8 ABV and probably was as it looks to be actively fermenting!
A good traditional ale.  Lemon, fruity, and cider flavor.  Finish is slightly sour, crisp and tart.

Fresh out of the fridge, this definitely needs some settling down, as it is overly carbonated and produces a huge meringue-like head. Once warmed and aerated, its a nice golden brew, heady with aromas. Grassy, lemon-pepper, hints of various fruits, cider, toffee-malt, whiskey  and a bit of cheesy yeast. The beer is distinctly, though subtly sour, with a slightly clean finish. Classicly, farmhouse-style, this is a great refresher, especially for fans of sour ales. I preferred this over their Seasonal Moneuse, which may have been a bit stale.

Head is initially huge, fizzy, off-white, mostly lasting.
Body is hazy light amber, dense particles of all sizes, bottle
conditioned. Aroma is moderately hoppy (flowers, grass, herbs, citrus -
lemon), moderately yeasty (barnyard, cobwebs), lightly malty (toasted
light bread), with notes of pear, cantaloupe, grape, and honey. Flavor
is moderately sweet, moderately acidic. Finish is
lightly sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, watery
texture, lively carbonation, lightly astringent. A very clean, brisk,
tart, and well-balanced saison.  The rustic, comforting, nostalgic farmhouse
aroma that has steadily made me a fan of this brewery is certainly on
display here. I like this a little more every time I have it.

tried in the 750ml bottle...huge head at the start, maybe up to 2" thick, but fairly quickly dissipating to approximately 1cm. slightly hazy golden hue. very fruity tart flavor that reminded me of the less sweet lambics. lots of floaties in this one boys and girls! overall a pretty crisp beer that was an unusual drinking experience for me.
